docs.lead_paragraph: BY necessity, the family doctor has turned into a marketing manager of sorts, working as a go-between for patients and their health care and medicine providers. These days, a doctor's message to patients might be: take two aspirin, call me in the morning and, before you go, sign up with my advertising partners for information on their latest products.

headline.main: Rules on patient privacy force companies to seek new ways to distribute samples and information.

docs.abstract: Patient privacy provisions of federal health insurance law that took full effect this year are forcing pharmaceutical and health care companies to re-examine their partnerships with physicians and pharmacies and their approaches to direct marketing drives; doctors, health plans and health care providers can no longer disclose any personally identifiable data about patients, including their names and addresses, for marketing purposes; advertisers are turning to variety of opt-in programs as way to put their products and names in front of consumers; programs that give doctors samples and coupons along with mail-in personal data cards seem to be working (M)
docs.snippet: BY necessity, the family doctor has turned into a marketing manager of sorts, working as a go-between for patients and their health care and medicine providers.    These days, a doctor's message to patients might be: take two aspirin, call me in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: When the House voted last week to let Americans import less expensive medicines from Canada and Europe, 53 senators signed a letter opposing the legislation, a letter that the industry trade group, which vigorously opposed the measure, hailed as proof of its argument that the bill would jeopardize patient safety. What the trade group, the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association, did not say, at the time, was that it helped coordinate the signature campaign.

headline.main: Drug Lobby Pushed Letter By Senators On Medicare

docs.abstract: Letter signed by 53 senators opposing House-approved bill to allow importation of medicines was coordinated in part by Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Assn, trade group that vigorously opposed measure (S)
docs.snippet: When the House voted last week to let Americans import less expensive medicines from Canada and Europe, 53 senators signed a letter opposing the legislation, a letter that the industry trade group, which vigorously opposed the measure, hailed as...

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of H.I.V. cases diagnosed in gay and bisexual men climbed for the third consecutive year in the United States in 2002, fueling fears that the disease might be poised for a major comeback in this high-risk group. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reported the finding today at the 2003 National H.I.V. Prevention Conference in Atlanta, also revealed that AIDS diagnoses overall had risen 2.2 percent to 42,136 last year.

headline.main: Cases of H.I.V. Rise in 2 U.S. Groups

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention representatives, addressing 2003 National HIV Prevention Conference in Atlanta, report number of HIV cases diagnosed in gay and bisexual men has risen for third consecutive year; report that overall AIDS diagnoses increased just over 2% to 42,136 last year; desire to track illness to help in understanding patterns of transmission have led to blood test that determines whether person has been infected in previous six months; test is expected to be in use by 2004 in areas that account for 93 percent of annual HIV infections (M)
